section.title: Introduction
section.para: The aim of the Chainsaw4WAS is to integrate Apache Chainsaw with WebSphere Application Server. Apache Chainsaw is a GUI-based log viewer based on the popular log4j framework. It ships with a number of plugins that can be used to receive log events from remote processes. However, for this to work, these processes must use log4j and must be configured with the corresponding log4j appenders.

On the other hand, WebSphere has a centralized logging subsystem that is exposed at the JMX level as an MBean called RasLoggingService. It processes log events from other WebSphere components as well as from the deployed applications, provided that these applications use one of the Jakarta Commons Logging (JCL) or java.util.logging (JUL) APIs. This is also the component that manages the well known SystemOut.log file. RasLoggingService supports JMX notifications, so that it is possible to connect to a remote WAS instance and receive log events from this server in realtime. The aim of the Chainsaw4WAS project is to allow these log events to be visualized in Apache Chainsaw.

The heard of the Chainsaw4WAS project is a custom log4j plugin (more precisely an implementation of the org.apache.log4j.plugins.Receiver interface) that connects to a local or remote RasLoggingService and that injects the received log events into the log4j framework. Please note that this project is currently based on Chainsaw version 2.0alpha-1, which is the last available release and has been built with log4j 1.3alpha-7. The 1.3 branch has been discontinued

section.title: Deployment options
section.para: Chainsaw4WAS can be used with two deployment variants:

listitem.para: Using the ZeroConf EAR. This requires deploying a special EAR file on each of the WAS instances to be monitored using Chainsaw. The code in this EAR file registers a notification listener on the local RasLoggingService and exposes the log events using a protocol supported out-of-the-box by Chainsaw. The component advertises itself using ZeroConf, so that it will be discovered automatically by Chainsaw. However, this only works if the workstation running Chainsaw is in the same network as the server.

The advantage of this deployment option is its simplicity and the fact that it works with the standard Chainsaw distribution. However, it is only suitable for test and development environments, but not for production environments, especially not for large scale WebSphere ND installations.

Using the RAS logging receiver plugin in Chainsaw. When this option is used, no particular setup is necessary on the WAS instances, and Chainsaw connects remotely to one or more RasLoggingService instances using one of the supported JMX connectors. This deployment option requires a specially built Chainsaw distribution because the plugin depends on libraries from the WebSphere runtime. For legal reasons, these libraries cannot be redistributed, and the custom Chainsaw4WAS distribution is therefore not available for download. Instead, it must be built from source code, which requires a local WebSphere 7.0 installation.

This option should be preferred for production environments. It is also more suitable for WAS ND installations, because only a connection to the deployment manager is required, but not to the individual application servers. Finally, this option should always be used in environments where ZeroConf doesn't work, i.e. if the application servers are located in a different network than the workstations running Chainsaw.
